natural problem: Legolas flips a fair coin 2008 times, and Gimli flips another fair coin 2009 times. What is the probability that Gimli flips more heads than Legolas?
natural solution: After Gimli has flipped his coin 2008 times, the probability that he has more heads than Legolas is equal the probability that Legolas has more heads than him. Call this probability $p$. Then there is a $1-2p$ probability that they have the same number of heads.

If Gimli already has more heads, he will have more heads after he flips again. If he has fewer heads, he cannot have more after just one more flip. If they are even, there is a $1/2$ chance he will flip another head, and therefore have more heads.
In all, Gimli flips more heads than Legolas with probability $p+\frac12(1-2p)=p+\frac12-p=\boxed{\frac{1}{2}}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes legolas_heads gimli_heads :: int
assumes h0 : "legolas_heads = binomial 2008 (2008 div 2)"
and h1 : "gimli_heads = binomial 2009 (2009 div 2)"
shows  "P(gimli_heads > legolas_heads) = 1 / 2"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Legolas flips a fair coin 2008 times, and Gimli flips another fair coin 2009 times. What is the probability that Gimli flips more heads than Legolas? The final Answer is \frac{1}{2}
 ### Proof
 After Gimli has flipped his coin 2008 times, the probability that he has more heads than Legolas is equal the probability that Legolas has more heads than him. Call this probability $p$. Then there is a $1-2p$ probability that they have the same number of heads.
 If Gimli already has more heads, he will have more heads after he flips again. If he has fewer heads, he cannot have more after just one more flip. If they are even, there is a $1/2$ chance he will flip another head, and therefore have more heads.
 In all, Gimli flips more heads than Legolas with probability $p+\frac12(1-2p)=p+\frac12-p=\boxed{\frac{1}{2}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes legolas_heads gimli_heads :: int
assumes h0 : "legolas_heads = binomial 2008 (2008 div 2)"
and h1 : "gimli_heads = binomial 2009 (2009 div 2)"
shows  "P(gimli_heads > legolas_heads) = 1 / 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Legolas and Gimli are playing a coin flipping game. Legolas flips 2008 coins and Gimli flips 2009 coins. What is the probability that Gimli gets more heads than Legolas? The final answer is $\frac{1}{2}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes Legolas_Gimli :: "(nat \<times> nat) \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> p. \<exists> n m. p = (n, m) \<and> 0 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 2008 \<and> 0 \<le> m \<and> m \<le> 2009 \<and> Legolas_Gimli p = (1 / 2) powr (n + m)"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>p. Legolas_Gimli p) {p. snd p > fst p} = 1 / 2"
a_1.formal solution:

 *)

theorem
fixes Legolas_Gimli :: "(nat \<times> nat) \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> p. \<exists> n m. p = (n, m) \<and> 0 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 2008 \<and> 0 \<le> m \<and> m \<le> 2009 \<and> Legolas_Gimli p = (1 / 2) powr (n + m)"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>p. Legolas_Gimli p) {p. snd p > fst p} = 1 / 2"

  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Legolas and Gimli are given a grid with dimensions 2008 by 2009. Each cell $(n, m)$ in the grid has a value $\frac{1}{2^{n + m}}$. Find the sum of the values in the cells where the second coordinate (m) is greater than the first coordinate (n). The final answer is $\frac{1}{2}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes legolas_heads gimli_heads legolas_flips gimli_flips :: real
assumes h0 : "legolas_flips = 2008"
and h1 : "gimli_flips = 2009"
and h2 : "legolas_heads \<le> 2008"
and h3 : "gimli_heads \<le> 2009"
and h4 : "0 \<le> legolas_heads"
and h5 : "0 \<le> gimli_heads"
and h6 : "gimli_heads > legolas_heads"
shows  "P (gimli_heads > legolas_heads) = (1/2 :: real)"
a_2.formal solution:

a_2.informal problem: Legolas and Gimli have a friendly coin flipping competition. Legolas flips a fair coin 2008 times, while Gimli flips the same coin 2009 times. Given that the number of heads each of them gets is a non-negative integer and Gimli gets more heads than Legolas, what is the probability that Gimli gets more heads than Legolas? The final answer is $\frac{1}{2}$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes legolas_heads gimli_heads :: "nat"
and legolas_flips gimli_flips :: "nat"
and probability :: "real"
assumes h0 : "legolas_flips = 2008"
and h1 : "gimli_flips = 2009"
and h2 : "0 \<le> probability"
and h3 : "probability \<le> 1"
and h4 : "probability = (\<Sum> i \<in> {0 .. legolas_flips}. binomial_coefficient gimli_flips i / (2 powr (legolas_flips + gimli_flips)))"
shows  "probability = 1 / 2"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 In all, Gimli flips more heads than Legolas with probability $p+\frac12(1-2p)=p+\frac12-p=\boxed{\frac{1}{2}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes legolas_heads gimli_heads :: "nat"
and legolas_flips gimli_flips :: "nat"
and probability :: "real"
assumes h0 : "legolas_flips = 2008"
and h1 : "gimli_flips = 2009"
and h2 : "0 \<le> probability"
and h3 : "probability \<le> 1"
and h4 : "probability = (\<Sum> i \<in> {0 .. legolas_flips}. binomial_coefficient gimli_flips i / (2 powr (legolas_flips + gimli_flips)))"
shows  "probability = 1 / 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Legolas and Gimli are having a coin flipping contest. Legolas flips a fair coin 2008 times and Gimli flips a fair coin 2009 times. What is the probability that Gimli ends up with more heads than Legolas? The final answer is $\frac{1}{2}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes legolas gimli :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. 0 \<le> legolas n \<and> legolas n \<le> 1"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. 0 \<le> gimli n \<and> gimli n \<le> 1"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. legolas n = 1 / 2"
and h3 : "\<forall>n. gimli n = 1 / 2"
shows  "prob {n. \<exists> l g. l < g \<and> (\<forall>i\<in>{1..2008}. (\<Sum>i\<in>{1..i}. legolas i) = l) \<and> (\<forall>i\<in>{1..2009}. (\<Sum>i\<in>{1..i}. gimli i) = g)} = 1 / 2"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Legolas flips a fair coin 2008 times, and Gimli flips another fair coin 2009 times. What is the probability that Gimli flips more heads than Legolas? The final Answer is \frac{1}{2}
 ### Proof
 After Gimli has flipped his coin 2008 times, the probability that he has more heads than Legolas is equal the probability that Legolas has more heads than him. Call this probability $p$. Then there is a $1-2p$ probability that they have the same number of heads.
 If Gimli already has more heads, he will have more heads after he flips again. If he has fewer heads, he cannot have more after just one more flip. If they are even, there is a $1/2$ chance he will flip another head, and therefore have more heads.
 In all, Gimli flips more heads than Legolas with probability $p+\frac12(1-2p)=p+\frac12-p=\boxed{\frac{1}{2}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes legolas gimli :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. 0 \<le> legolas n \<and> legolas n \<le> 1"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. 0 \<le> gimli n \<and> gimli n \<le> 1"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. legolas n = 1 / 2"
and h3 : "\<forall>n. gimli n = 1 / 2"
shows  "prob {n. \<exists> l g. l < g \<and> (\<forall>i\<in>{1..2008}. (\<Sum>i\<in>{1..i}. legolas i) = l) \<and> (\<forall>i\<in>{1..2009}. (\<Sum>i\<in>{1..i}. gimli i) = g)} = 1 / 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Legolas and Gimli participate in a contest where each of them has to perform a task 2008 and 2009 times, respectively. The probability of Legolas completing each task successfully is $\frac{1}{2}$, and the probability of Gimli completing each task successfully is also $\frac{1}{2}$. What is the probability that the total number of tasks Legolas completes successfully is less than the total number of tasks Gimli completes successfully? The final answer is $\frac{1}{2}$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and P_Gimli P_Legolas :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "n = 2008"
and h1 : "\<forall>k. P_Legolas k = (1 / 2) powr (n + 1)"
and h2 : "\<forall>k. P_Gimli k = (1 / 2) powr (n + 2)"
and h3 : "sum (\<lambda>k. P_Legolas k * P_Gimli (k + 1)) {0..n} = (1 / 2)"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>k. P_Legolas k * P_Gimli (k + 1)) {0..n} = 1 / 2"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Legolas flips a fair coin 2008 times, and Gimli flips another fair coin 2009 times. What is the probability that Gimli flips more heads than Legolas? The final Answer is \frac{1}{2}
 ### Proof
 After Gimli has flipped his coin 2008 times, the probability that he has more heads than Legolas is equal the probability that Legolas has more heads than him. Call this probability $p$. Then there is a $1-2p$ probability that they have the same number of heads.
 If Gimli already has more heads, he will have more heads after he flips again. If he has fewer heads, he cannot have more after just one more flip. If they are even, there is a $1/2$ chance he will flip another head, and therefore have more heads.
 In all, Gimli flips more heads than Legolas with probability $p+\frac12(1-2p)=p+\frac12-p=\boxed{\frac{1}{2}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and P_Gimli P_Legolas :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "n = 2008"
and h1 : "\<forall>k. P_Legolas k = (1 / 2) powr (n + 1)"
and h2 : "\<forall>k. P_Gimli k = (1 / 2) powr (n + 2)"
and h3 : "sum (\<lambda>k. P_Legolas k * P_Gimli (k + 1)) {0..n} = (1 / 2)"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>k. P_Legolas k * P_Gimli (k + 1)) {0..n} = 1 / 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: In the year 2008, Legolas and Gimli participate in an archery competition. The probability that Legolas hits the target on his $k^{th}$ shot is given by $P_{Legolas}(k) = \frac{1}{2^{2009}}$. Similarly, the probability that Gimli hits the target on his $k^{th}$ shot is given by $P_{Gimli}(k) = \frac{1}{2^{2010}}$. If the probability that Legolas hits the target on his $k^{th}$ shot and Gimli hits the target on his $(k+1)^{th}$ shot is represented by the sum $\sum_{k=0}^{2008} P_{Legolas}(k) \cdot P_{Gimli}(k+1)$, show that this sum equals $\frac{1}{2}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes legolas_flips gimli_flips :: nat and prob :: real
assumes h0 : "legolas_flips = 2008"
and h1 : "gimli_flips = 2009"
and h2 : "prob = (\<Sum>n\<in>{0..<legolas_flips + 1}. ((binomial gimli_flips n) * (binomial legolas_flips (n - 1)) / (2 ^ (gimli_flips + legolas_flips))))"
shows  "prob = 1 / 2"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Legolas flips a fair coin 2008 times, and Gimli flips another fair coin 2009 times. What is the probability that Gimli flips more heads than Legolas? The final Answer is \frac{1}{2}
 ### Proof
 After Gimli has flipped his coin 2008 times, the probability that he has more heads than Legolas is equal the probability that Legolas has more heads than him. Call this probability $p$. Then there is a $1-2p$ probability that they have the same number of heads.
 If Gimli already has more heads, he will have more heads after he flips again. If he has fewer heads, he cannot have more after just one more flip. If they are even, there is a $1/2$ chance he will flip another head, and therefore have more heads.
 In all, Gimli flips more heads than Legolas with probability $p+\frac12(1-2p)=p+\frac12-p=\boxed{\frac{1}{2}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes legolas_flips gimli_flips :: nat and prob :: real
assumes h0 : "legolas_flips = 2008"
and h1 : "gimli_flips = 2009"
and h2 : "prob = (\<Sum>n\<in>{0..<legolas_flips + 1}. ((binomial gimli_flips n) * (binomial legolas_flips (n - 1)) / (2 ^ (gimli_flips + legolas_flips))))"
shows  "prob = 1 / 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Legolas flips a fair coin 2008 times, and Gimli flips a fair coin 2009 times. What is the probability that the number of heads Legolas flips is one less than the number of heads Gimli flips? The final answer is $\frac{1}{2}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes legolas_flips gimli_flips :: nat
and P_legolas P_gimli :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "legolas_flips = 2008"
and h1 : "gimli_flips = 2009"
and h2 : "(\<forall>n. P_legolas n = (1/2) powr n) \<and> (\<forall>n. P_gimli n = (1/2) powr (n+1))"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>n. P_legolas n * P_gimli n) {0..<gimli_flips} = 1/2"
a_7.formal solution:

 In all, Gimli flips more heads than Legolas with probability $p+\frac12(1-2p)=p+\frac12-p=\boxed{\frac{1}{2}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes legolas_flips gimli_flips :: nat
and P_legolas P_gimli :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "legolas_flips = 2008"
and h1 : "gimli_flips = 2009"
and h2 : "(\<forall>n. P_legolas n = (1/2) powr n) \<and> (\<forall>n. P_gimli n = (1/2) powr (n+1))"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>n. P_legolas n * P_gimli n) {0..<gimli_flips} = 1/2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: In a coin-flipping game, Legolas flips a fair coin 2008 times, and Gimli flips the same coin 2009 times. The probability of Legolas getting heads in the n-th flip is $P_\text{Legolas}(n) = \frac{1}{2^n}$, and the probability of Gimli getting heads in the n-th flip is $P_\text{Gimli}(n) = \frac{1}{2^{n+1}}$. Find the sum of the product of the probabilities of each corresponding flip for Legolas and Gimli up to Gimli's 2009 flips. The final answer is $\frac{1}{2}$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> p"
and h1 : "p \<le> 1"
and h2 : "p = probability of Gimli flipping more heads than Legolas in 2008 and 2009 coin flips"
shows  "p = 1 / 2"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 In all, Gimli flips more heads than Legolas with probability $p+\frac12(1-2p)=p+\frac12-p=\boxed{\frac{1}{2}}$.
 *)

fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> p"
and h1 : "p \<le> 1"
and h2 : "p = probability of Gimli flipping more heads than Legolas in 2008 and 2009 coin flips"
shows  "p = 1 / 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Gimli and Legolas each flip a fair coin 2008 times. What is the probability that Gimli flips more heads than Legolas? The final answer is $\frac{1}{2}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes flips_legolas flips_gimli :: nat
and prob_heads_legolas prob_heads_gimli :: real
and prob_more_heads_gimli :: real
assumes h0 : "flips_legolas = 2008"
and h1 : "flips_gimli = 2009"
and h2 : "prob_heads_legolas = 1 / 2"
and h3 : "prob_heads_gimli = 1 / 2"
and h4 : "prob_more_heads_gimli = (\<Sum>i \<in> {0..<flips_legolas}. (flips_gimli choose i) * ((prob_heads_gimli) powr (flips_gimli - i)) * ((1 - prob_heads_gimli) powr i))"
shows  "prob_more_heads_gimli = 1 / 2"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Legolas flips a fair coin 2008 times, and Gimli flips another fair coin 2009 times. What is the probability that Gimli flips more heads than Legolas? The final Answer is \frac{1}{2}
 ### Proof
 After Gimli has flipped his coin 2008 times, the probability that he has more heads than Legolas is equal the probability that Legolas has more heads than him. Call this probability $p$. Then there is a $1-2p$ probability that they have the same number of heads.
 If Gimli already has more heads, he will have more heads after he flips again. If he has fewer heads, he cannot have more after just one more flip. If they are even, there is a $1/2$ chance he will flip another head, and therefore have more heads.
 In all, Gimli flips more heads than Legolas with probability $p+\frac12(1-2p)=p+\frac12-p=\boxed{\frac{1}{2}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes flips_legolas flips_gimli :: nat
and prob_heads_legolas prob_heads_gimli :: real
and prob_more_heads_gimli :: real
assumes h0 : "flips_legolas = 2008"
and h1 : "flips_gimli = 2009"
and h2 : "prob_heads_legolas = 1 / 2"
and h3 : "prob_heads_gimli = 1 / 2"
and h4 : "prob_more_heads_gimli = (\<Sum>i \<in> {0..<flips_legolas}. (flips_gimli choose i) * ((prob_heads_gimli) powr (flips_gimli - i)) * ((1 - prob_heads_gimli) powr i))"
shows  "prob_more_heads_gimli = 1 / 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: In a contest, Legolas and Gimli flip coins. Legolas flips a coin 2008 times, and Gimli flips a coin 2009 times. Both coins have a probability of 1/2 of landing heads. What is the probability that Gimli gets more heads than Legolas? The final answer is 1/2.
